text: hi everyone Anthony Fantana here
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new white suns
record totem these guys are new york
rock outfit and this is their third
full-length LP i dug on their sophomore
album sinew back in 2012 an album that
was one of my favorites of that year an
LP that I thought was really refreshing
in its chaotic approach chaotic approach
to noise rock yes noise rock bands from
this genre that you may love or remember
like Sonic Youth or flipper
Boris big black or Jesus Lizard all
bands that have far more composure than
white Suns and while white Sun songs do
have an element of composition to them
there's a lot of very visceral guitars
and drums that seem pretty planned out
and pre-written on this thing lyrics
that go from really wild twisted dark
poetry to unadulterated anger and there
are some pretty ambient interludes where
the sounds the noises that run
throughout them seem so specific and so
treated and so I guess fuss over that
they couldn't possibly have just been
made up right there in the moment as the
band was just playing or performing this
record so there's really a mix of the
sounds on this album being just so
unpredictable in sporadic and very
purposeful there's a very structural
element to this LP and many of the songs
on here have a variety of different
parts however the tracks that white Suns
pull together on this record are so
psychotic and overwhelming that it makes
it almost impossible sometimes to even
concentrate or make note of these things
or even think about things like
technical ability or guitar tone well I
think has consistently been so
impressive with white Sons is how they
mix noise and rock music typically a lot
of the bands that I enjoy to sit in the
genre just sound like rock music or punk
rock music with a very strong noise
element white Suns blend these two
genres together so well that it never
really sounds like I'm listening to
you just won or just the other I think
they're also great a bringing about the
emotions I typically expect from and and
feel with both honors as well I mean
this album to me is it's visceral it's
exciting it's aggressive like a great
Punk LP and yet it's disorienting and
grading like a very good noise album to
totem to me is just a clash of raw
adrenaline and the most bleak and
tortured of human emotions the band is
constantly shifting back and forth
between these overwhelming noise rock
pieces and these very subtle eerie more
ambient tracks on the album that really
seem to segue these heavier more
hard-hitting spots and these softer
moments make for some really eerie
interludes and I sit there paranoid
waiting for the band is going to come
back at me swinging with a spiked bat of
aah so there definitely is an element of
surprise to this record that was there
when I was first listening to it and
this surprise element is something that
I do find a lot of Noise music records
rely on that wish to sporadically jar
the listener by just introducing them to
all these new and wild changes in pace
and sounds over a very short period of
time however I also felt that many of
these songs were sticking with me they
had elements that were worth remembering
or had kind of a spotlight on them or
were presented in a way where the band
really wanted to make an emotional
impact on the listener with this part of
the song the listener has to really
gravitate to this part meaning that
while disorienting yes white Suns make
sure to pack this album with highlights
Plus on top of it I think the band's
done a really great job of building on
the sound set that they had on their
last record I'm finding more layers on
totem I'm finding more colors overall
some really dissonant grading just ah
torturous Electronics intense feedback
this LP opens up with priests and
laboratory
killer opener for this thing later
another heavy track on here clairvoyant
which is one of the most pummeling spots
on this entire LP the intro of the song
eventually this heavy intro gives way to
these noisy wall
of sound that seemed so huge and so
monstrous that it's actually difficult
to think of them being created by the
human hand much less regular rock
instrumentation it's so noisy it's so
layered it's so impenetrable and yet
there's sort of an element of warmth to
this as well that I feel slightly
comforted by eventually this wall of
sound dies down I love the over
modulated bass rumbles that are kind of
coming in and the strong out guitars and
then the most amazing vocal on this
entire LP pours through my gods face is
made of bearers my gods faces like my
father's this song to me is is easily
one of the most twisted displays of
human expression I've ever been an
audience to especially as the song just
goes into this insane downward spiral of
noisy guitars and drums and just
repeated shouting of pleading out played
it out this album is no hawk in the park
there's the Csonka thesis has a really
spaced out rhythm sort of primal
slow-moving groove this B is stacked
with layers of dissonance that are kind
of difficult to decipher the origin of
and the manic vocals all over this thing
are just so passionate to me they just
reach down in the in the most fed-up of
emotions and then amplify them a
thousand times typically that that just
raw impossible to ignore emotion is what
I like so much about the very shouty
generally screamy vocals on white Suns
records even though there are more
toned-down vocals on this LP just very
stone-faced flat lines spoken word and
even though if you take the vocals and
just separate them out of what you're
hearing musically on this record and
just analyze them for themselves they
don't sound like much I think the music
does a great job of just setting the
stage for what the vocals do and just
complements them so well I mean the
vocals sound like hell and the music
sounds like hell and it's just hell on
hell on hell now these heavier noisier
more eventful tracks like I said earlier
are segwayed with softer
her songs which if you listen to them by
themselves they don't really sound like
much but they do provide some
much-needed breathing room between these
very tracks and that's not to say they
should immediately go into the
background in your mind as soon as they
come on because the sounds on a lot of
them seems like white Suns really really
concentrated on creating some weird
strange out-there textures for these
interludes and then there's the world of
lock 2 which is a track that features an
incredibly soft moment paired with a
louder more intense finish it actually
goes over really well it makes me wish
more tracks on here mixed these two
worlds together though I do think that
you know it works really well in the
context of sort of looking at the entire
album as a whole overall I got to say I
think white Suns really did it again on
this record they came through with an
even more impressive combination of
noise and rock music to the point where
with their last album yeah there were
moments that felt more noisy there were
moments that felt more rocky but here it
really feels like they've blurred those
lines to the point where I mean it
doesn't really sound like either I think
the production on this thing is better
there's more sounds it's heavier I think
the lyrics the poetry the vocal delivery
is a lot more stunning and emotionally
impactful they really fine-tune their
ability to bring together eye widening
sonic weirdness with just explosive punk
rock energy I'm feeling a decent too
strong eight on this thing transition if
you've given this record to listen what
did you think of it did you love it did
you hate it why what do you think I
should review next and and that's it
Anthony Fantana white suns forever
